"It may look like little more than a glorified concrete shed, but this humble home represents the future of prefabrication and architecture within every recycled fibre of its 3D-printed body. Earlier this month, innovative Shanghai-based company WinSun assembled an impressive 10 of these 3D-printed homes in 24 hours, each costing less than $5000 to construct. The prototype turns house manufacturing and technology on its head, with four specially engineered 6.6m x 10m x 32m printers used to produce the structural components of the homes â spraying layer by layer of wall, floor and bracing offsite."

"The 14th edition of SIAO, the International Handicraft Show of Ouagadougou, originally scheduled to take place from October 31 to November 9, 2014 is postponed to a date to be specified later.   An interesting (and scary) video about what is really going on with herbicide chemical companies!  After Tyrone Hayes said that a chemical was harmful, its maker pursued him.  "Syngenta, one of the largest agribusinesses in the world, had asked Hayes to conduct experiments on the herbicide atrazine, which is applied to more than half the corn in the United States." "But, when Hayes discovered that atrazine might impede the sexual development of frogs, his dealings with Syngenta became strained, and he ended his relationship with the company."

If a municipality makes it illegal to disconnect from any given utility, they are in essence making off grid living illegal." http://www.collective-evolution.com/2014/03/09/florida-makes-off-grid-living-illegal-mandates-all-homes-must-be-connected-to-an-electricity-grid/  Another Case of State Hassle  "Earlier this year, Texas state brought several SWAT teams to a sustainable community and threatened to shut it down. Happy that I am not in Ouaga right now!  Originally I had planned to visit Burkina Faso in October-November this year to participate in the SIAO Craft Fair, which is held every second year in the capital Ouagadougou. This year it would run from today, Friday 31 October and throughout next week until Sunday, November 9th. However, the fair was cancelled a month ago due to the Ebola epidemic in West Africa. The authorities would not take the risk of 400,000 exhibitors and visitors from across Africa and Europe packed closely together in the exhibition halls with the danger of getting Ebola to the country and spreading it further around. I then decided to postpone my visit until after Christmas, which is also a better time for me.  In light of the events in Ouagadougou in recent days, I am glad that I am not there now. There have been massive demonstrations and there are reports of five dead and 60 wounded. A man was killed yesterday by a stray bullet just around the corner from the guest house "Chez Giuliana" where I would have stayed.   Here's a report from Ouaga: http://www.ilfattoquotidiano.it/2014/10/30/in-burkina-faso-dove-colpo-alle-porte-fuori-proiettili-rabbia/1180896/
As it happened: Burkina Faso unrest Posted 30. October 2014 at 18:01  Thank you and goodbye We're ending our live coverage of the dramatic events in Burkina Faso, where street protests have shaken the 27-year rule of President Blaise Compaore and left at least five people dead. The president has declared a state of emergency and promised talks with protesters. But this could be a case of too little, too late, with several reports now of high-level meetings between the opposition and army. This live page will close but you can follow further developments on the BBC News website. We leave you with this image from today of two young protesters - standing at a crossroads for their country.  http://www.bbc.com/news/live/world-africa-29831591

'Take, make, Dispose' is how our current linear economic model is described. Take raw materials from the ground, make a product then dispose of it back into the ground. However, with the rapid rise of consumerism in the 20th century, we are now running out of raw materials and places to dispose of waste and thats not even mentioning the environmental damage caused in between.  The Circular Economy is more progressive, environmentally friendly and efficient economic model, one that mimics nature and where there is no such thing as waste.  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AayNb89jKLA&feature=youtu.be

Despite its low consumption it lights as a 90/100 watt incandescent bulb, which represents a saving of over 96% and 50% compared to conventional LED technology, while providing more light, as the company ensures manufacturer.  The iWop bulb is also the only repairable and upgradeable in the world, it is a product made "without obsolescence," says the company, and can be used "for life". So all kinds of waste are avoided because it is not necessary to replace it with another. Get Free Home Heating With an Attached Greenhouse Off Grid Living: https://www.offgridworld.com/subscribe/ #offgrid #homesteading #gardening #greenhouse
The renovated 100-year-old solar-powered cabin is 450 square feet with a 225 square foot addition, for a total living space of 675 square feet.  It has a huge garden for growing food and a root cellar for food storage.  Water for the cabin and the garden comes from a spring that sits above it.  The cabin uses wood stove heat, with additional heat and light provided by the sunroom & greenhouse addition.  Solar curtains are used to keep the cabin cooler in the summer and to keep heat in during the winter. http://www.offgridworld.com/gorgeous-off-grid-renovated-100-year-old-solar-cabin-in-the-forest/

Light over Africa - New Book by Folkecenter August 2015 Published by: Nordic Folkecenter for Renewable Energy, Denmark  DKK 85 (EUR 12) + Shipping Hardback, 64 pages B5 (176 Ã 250 mm) ISBN: 978-87-7778-002-8 Publication date: Aug. 2015  Brief: Over the years Folkecenter has transferred renewable energy know-how around the globe; it has organized solar lighting projects in Africa since 1998. By 2015 Folkecenter in cooperation with local NGOâs and suppliers has installed solar systems in over 300 rural schools in Mali, Uganda and Burkina Faso in the villages less than 5 % of the people have access to electricity. In the book, Light over Africa, you will find the background of the solar lighting projects, the impact for the local people, the keys to success and the next challenge: a plan for solar lighting in 10 000 village schools in the above-mentioned 3 African countries. Here two thirds of the populations are illiterates; in the countryside even more. With the implementing of the new plan 2 million village inhabitants (10 000 schools, each 200 students) will have the opportunity to attend evening school to learn to read and write. The investment will be EUR 10 million (EUR 1 000 for each school).  About Folkecenter: The Nordic Folkecenter for Renewable Energy is a non-profit, independent, organization that provides research, development of technology, training and information for the implementation of renewable energy technologies and energy savings in Denmark and throughout the world.  http://www.folkecenter.net/gb/news/press/light-over-africa/

" In a move that could help decide the future of GM crops in Africa, Burkina Faso has abandoned GM Bt cotton. The country has begun a complete phaseout of the crop, citing the inferior lint quality of GM cultivars.  This story of a major GMO failure is documented in a new briefing[1] by Brian Dowd-Uribe, Assistant Professor in the International Studies Department at the University of San Francisco and Matthew A. Schnurr, Associate Professor in the Department of International Development Studies at Dalhousie University. " New research shows regulatory âsafeâ limits for glyphosate may not be safe at all.  The approval process for glyphosate herbicide is disputed because the commercial formulations contain additives or co-formulants, which are more toxic than glyphosate alone.  In a new study published in the International Journal of Environmental Research and Public Health, the researchers measured the endocrine disruptive effects of the co-formulants of six glyphosate herbicides. They measured the activity of aromatase, a key enzyme for the balance of sex hormones, in human placental cells, using a method validated by the OECD to assess endocrine disruptors."  http://www.gmwatch.org/news/latest-news/16742-co-formulants-of-glyphosate-herbicides-are-endocrine-disruptors

A beautiful example of community acceptance and participation.
Architecture, KÃ©rÃ© explains, is basically a social process -  especially in the poorer and less developed regions of the world.  It is about integrating the people, you build for, making them feel, it is their project. In this way, they identify with the building and are proud of it.

Weaving modern cloth with Victorian loom  When Daniel Harris rescued a rusting loom from an old barn in rural Wales, it led to the creation of London's first micro-mill.  Established in 2011, the London Cloth Company uses traditional weaving techniques and a range of equipment dating all the way back to the 1870s. Three years on, the company supplies woven cloth to a growing number of designers, companies and individuals.

In 1395 it was bought by the church and over 200 years later, around 1600, the house got its first glazed windows."

THE WAVE  In spring 1967, in Palo Alto, California, history teacher Ron Jones conducted an experiment with his class of 15-year-olds to sample the experience of the attraction and rise of the Nazis in Germany before World War II.  In a matter of days the experiment began to get out of control, as those attracted to the movement became aggressive zealots and the rigid rules invited confusion and chaos.  This story has attracted considerable attention over the years through films, books, plays and musicals, and verges on urban legend.  It serves as a teaching tool, to facilitate discussion of those uncomfortable topics of history, human nature, psychology, group behavior, intolerance and hate. The primary purpose of this website is to document and separate fact from fiction about the original experiment.  As the story is told and re-told, reported and fictionalized, Video: https://youtu.be/ICng-KRxXJ8  Read more: http://www.thewavehome.com/

Pedal-Powered âUn-knittingâ Machine   Make do and unmend? Meet the âun-knittingâ machine, a pedal-powered apparatus designed to recycle unwanted knitwear. The curious contraption is the brainchild of Imogen Hedges, a London-based product-and-furniture designer who discovered that charity shops sometimes spend hours unraveling sweaters by hand. âThey can make more money out of selling the wool than they can from the sweaters,â says the Kingston University graduate, one of a select group of student designers exhibiting at the The National Centre for Craft & Design this month.  YARN AGAIN Built around an old bicycle frame, Hedgesâs machine requires little more than a well-oiled pair of legs to run. The âun-knitterâ sits on a chair on one end, unraveling the garment as itâs pulled along the circumference of the wheel. Wool, which retains its elasticity better than other fibers, works best, as do knits derived from continuous lengths of fiber. To eliminate kinks, the yarn passes through the steam of a electric kettle. Finally, it finds its way to a hand-cranked spindle, where itâs rewound into a ball for re-knitting.

"In a recent report, the UK Soil Association found that organically grown cotton has about half the climate change impact compared to conventionally produced cotton -- primarily due to the avoidance of chemical fertilisers and practices related to tractor use and irrigation. Organic farming methods -- and the social benefits of it -- also help make famers and their communities, more resilient to the challenges of climate change.  Organically grown cotton also only uses about â of the energy (e.g. oil, electricity) than its conventionally produced counterpart, uses just 9% of the amount of surface and ground water (i.e. lake or river water) compared to conventional cotton, and bans the use of hazardous chemicals and GMO cotton."

No noise - No fuel - No pollution  SOLAR IMPULSE Bertrand Piccard and AndrÃ© Borschberg, have set out to achieve something that still seems impossible today: the First Round-The-World Solar Flight, powered only by the sun, with no fuel or polluting emissions.  In line with the Piccard Family tradition of scientific exploration and protection of the environment, Solar Impulse wants to demonstrate that clean technologies can achieve impossible goals. The record breaking solo flight of 5 days and 5 nights without fuel from Nagoya to Hawaii gives a clear message : everybody could use the planeâs technologies on the ground to halve our worldâs energy consumption, save natural resources and improve our quality of life. This message is being spread by the pilots to the general public, students, key decision-makers and entrepreneurs all over the world.
SOLAR IMPULSE "You take off with this plane, and it is like a jump into the FUTURE.  No noise, no pollution, no fuel.  And you fly in the sky with modern technology.  Then when you land it is like a jump back into the PAST.  Most cars are still polluting. Most houses are still bad insulated.  Most technology is old."
Before landing in Mountain View, Solar Impulse 2 flown by Bertrand Piccard spent 3 hours flying over the Bay Area. He realized this flyover 54 hours after taking off from Hawaii.

"The European Commission must take seriously the potential risks to human health posed by these soybeans and their residues. It should not allow their import until suitable biosafety tests are in place. I am especially concerned that pesticide-contaminated FG72 GM soy could enter the food chain and be fed to infants in soy-based baby formulas.   Others who eat poultry, pork, or beef from animals fed with GM corn and soy could consume residues of endocrine disruptors active at very low levels, in the parts per billion. They could also be eating probable or possible carcinogens such as glufosinate, dicamba, 2,4-D, isoxaflutole, and glyphosate â all of which are used on GM herbicide-tolerant crops.   Because of weed resistance to herbicides, US agriculture is on a pesticide treadmill. Europeans should keep the products of that treadmill out of their food and feed supplies."

SOCIAL FRIDGES In Argentina, more and more "social fridges", installed in the street offer free meals to people who approach it. There's even one in the famous Plaza de Mayo, in front of the presidential palace in the heart of Buenos Aires.  How to explain this phenomenon?  This, at least in part, is a way to meet the increasing poverty in the country. Since 2001 NGOs or organizations like Catholic Relief Services have opened soup kitchens, that is to say, free restaurants or food distribution centers, as there are in France for the poor. But a few years ago, a restaurateur had the idea of installing a refrigerator on his sidewalk and to store cooked food in individual trays wrapped in cellophane that passersby could withdraw freely. Food that would otherwise have ended in the trash, was now available to people in need. Anyone could use it without being asked anything.  This has been successful and others have copied the concept in several parts of the country, especially in front of public hospitals in poor suburbs where, clearly, many of those who come for free treatment also struggle to support themselves with food. In reality, the concept of "social fridges" comes from Germany, where they are longstanding. But it is true that these street refrigerators have multiplied in recent months in Argentina following the increased number of people in need  During the last two years of the presidency of Cristina Kirchner, living conditions have worsened for many Argentines, especially because of inflation. According to the indicator of the Catholic University, considered the most reliable, at the end of 2015, 29% of the population lived below the poverty line. And during the first three months of this year, that percentage has increased nearly 5 points,.
CLIMATE CHANGE? "Bangladesh is prone to electrical storms but this year they have been particularly severe. Experts suggest a general rise in temperatures and deforestation may be factors."

"According to recent figures, the country emits around 1.5 million tonnes of carbon annually, while its forests absorb over 6 million tonnes. Bhutan is aiming for zero net greenhouse gas emissions, zero-waste by 2030 and to grow 100 percent organic food by 2020.  The country would also like to increase its share of renewables, while decreasing its reliance on hydropower and electricity imports in the winter. So, itâs currently exploring wind, biogas and solar." Urban Farming "With so few resources to go around, one increasingly popular way of fighting malnutrition is by empowering local people like Edith to produce their own nutritious food, which can feed vulnerable mothers and children, and be sold in order to provide them with an income. Edith is one of more than 1,000 urban farmers in Bulawayo, Zimbabwe, who formed groups to support their own nutrition and that of the city as a whole. Edith grows iron-rich foods like beetroot, spinach, onions, tomatoes, and cabbages." https://www.one.org/us/2016/05/03/meet-edith-a-widow-and-urban-farmer-whos-helping-feed-her-family-and-her-city/

SLAVERY DID NOT END WITH ABOLITION IN THE 19th CENTURY. According to the just released Global Slavery Index the number of people living in "modern slavery" has increased by 28% in two years, from 35.8 million in 2014 to 45.8 million today.  "Incidences of slavery were found in all 167 countries in the index, with India home to the largest total number with an estimated 18.4 million slaves among its 1.3 billion population.  But North Korea ranked as worst in terms of concentration with one in every 20 people - or 4.4 percent of its 25 million population - in slavery and its government doing the least to end this with reports of state-sanctioned forced labour.  About 58 percent of people living in slavery are in five countries - India, China, Pakistan, Bangladesh and Uzbekistan."  Read the full article: http://news.trust.org/item/20160530230329-t34j6/

BAREFOOT COLLEGE BRINGING LIGHT TO THE WORLD Barefoot Collegeâs mission seems humble at first; bring solar energy to the most rural locations in the world. But their vision goes so much further than that. They believe that the rural poor, already have within their communities the capacity, wisdom, and skills to create better quality of life, vibrant economic opportunities, and stronger civil societies.  When Barefoot enters a village, they do not look for the youngest, fittest, or best educated of the tribe. They seek out the wisest of the villageâs Mamas, or grandmothers, and offer her the opportunity to travel to a college in India to learn the skills necessary to install, operate, and maintain  solar home systems for their village.  @[100001560178227:2048:Aung Phonn Kyaw] @[100000147203468:2048:Tahir Mahmood] @[100003617485672:2048:Ghansham Jadhav] @[100000254508588:2048:William Bazie] @[1514965202:2048:Samuel Boamah] @[100001560558441:2048:Kalifa Kanteh] @[100005158903276:2048:Ouedraogo Madi] @[100000270047359:2048:Yoshinari Suzuki]  @[100001905243861:2048:Bastian Acevedo Bustos] @[523680788:2048:Kardelen Afrodit Adsal] @[100003369316712:2048:Isa Leff] @[577455116:2048:Sheila Morgo Monne] @[100004239871943:2048:Leire Gorro] @[593480474:2048:Michel Chamy]

"Netherlands-based ReGen Villages and architectural partners EFFEKT (Denmark) want to build sustainable communities for the 21st century.  Since revealing plans for their modern eco-village at the Venice Biennale at the end of May, ReGen Villages say they have seen a âfirestormâ of viral activity and 6,500 interested emails. âWhat they are saying is: âWe want in desperately: this is our dream,â"says California-based Ehrlich.  âWeâre getting emails from PhD [students], family members, older couples who want to downsize with their friends â¦ communities of people reaching out to us because they see we have essentially done the homework for them.â  That homework involves combining the most modern technologies to build a circle of homes in a closed-loop system that produces its own solar and biogas power, grows organic vegetables, farms fish and chickens, harvests water and recycles waste into fertiliser. Homes, enclosed in greenhouses to âextend the warm seasonâ.  ReGen sees the answer to the worldâs growing population and scarcer resources in self-sustaining, rural communities. It will start building its first 100 homes in Almere Oosterwold in the eastern Netherlands this summer. It is planning projects in Denmark and northern Europe, then hopes to create designs for every climate."

"Their are over 20,000 Species of Edible plants on the planet, but Humans use only about 20 Species to provide 90% for our food. So why do we Utilize so little when there is so much? Joseph Simcox, a passion driven Food Plant Ecologist has traveled to over 100 countries, finding, documenting & eating all the plants we don't use. From the deep jungles of Papua New Guinea To the vast deserts of Namibia Africa, he sheds light on the extraordinary wonders of the edible plant world. In this Film Joe meets up with his brother Patrick Simcox in Peru, along with there team, and ventures deep into the Amazon Jungle to document, eat, & shed light on a small fraction of some the most amazing things nature has to offer. Come along on the Adventure!"  For more Info Visit: explorewithjoseph.com  Shot & Edited By: Anthony B. Rodriguez For more Visit: AnthonyBRodriguez.com

"Hair embroidery is a particular technique practiced by lay Buddhist women to create devotional images. The embroiderers used their own hair as threads and applied them on silk to stitch figures. Scholars contend that this tradition started from the Tang Dynasty (618-907). However, the resurgence of this practice in the Ming period (1368-1644) was related to two historical factors: the spread of the cult of Guanyin, the most prevalent Chinese female deity, and the proliferation of embroidering Guanyin during late imperial China. In recent works on womenâs talent, scholars have cursorily mentioned hair embroidery, but they have failed to study it in detail. Hair embroideries of Guanyin offer us a felicitous window on this tradition. Hair embroidery was a unique site where women externalized part of their body to communicate with Guanyin.  Hair embroidered Tapestries by Yuan Miao. Since the time of the Tang Dynasty, hair has been used to embroider sacred tapestries, which transmit the wisdom of spiritual leaders through generations. This video will take you to a remote town in the plains of southern China where you can witness the creation of these beautiful spiritual embroideries featuring the art of Yuan Miao, a dakini and zen master, and traditional Guanyins."  Source: New Century Foundation www.newcenturyfoundation.org
Burkina Faso: Seizure of nearly 30 tons of chicken unfit for consumption.  Two vehicles registered abroad refused to obey the police control.  Drivers fled leaving nearly 30 tons of frozen chickens at a station in Ouagadougou. It was discovered that the chickens are unfit for consumption. The chickens were therefore incinerated.  Police also discovered in a warehouse near the same station boxes of tomatoes and various other packaged goods in cartons not corresponding to the origin of the products.  In July this year, 79 tons of rice, two tons of frozen chicken and a large quantity of fish unfit for consumption, were seized by the authorities.  One also remembers the OBOUF case in February 2015, where nearly 1,300 tons of outdated cans were seized in a warehouse in Ouagadougou.

GREAT!!! AFTER 38 YEARS OF CONCERN THE US FDA FINALLY BANS TRICLOSAN IN HAND SOAP AND BODY WASH.  "Since 1978 concern has grown for the use of these chemicals in a daily household setting, after studies found Triclosan in the urine and breast milk of about 75 percent of individuals. More studies have linked Triclosan to bacterial resistance and hormonal changes, and have even showed that the presence of Triclosan can remain in the environment for an excessive amount of time."

Ali Tapsoba de Goamma: "The message weâd like to share with the world is that Burkina Faso is a concrete example of the failure of GMOs. We cannot imagine that today, after what they have seen in Burkina Faso, a country would still dare to engage in GMOs. What we would like to say is that there are still multinationals that want to control our food. We tell you, he who fights against the seed, controls production, he who controls production will control our food, and he who controls our food, will control our way of thinking. To govern our way of thinking is a global governance that will bring us to slavery. To conclude, we say to all of the countries of the world â of America, of Europe, of Asia and of Africa â to unite, together, to stop them from governing our seed and governing our way of thinking. When it comes to Africa, we are in the process of putting together an African Front for Sovereignty of Food and the People of Burkina Faso because henceforth, we will not let Monsanto manipulate the governments of our countries. We will join our struggles: if something happens in one Africain country, all the other African countries will stand up against it. This is what we will put into place as a key tool in the fight the next few days with the African Front, with the ultimate aim of achieving Food Sovereignty. We will establish a relationship with India, with other European countries to share our experiences, and you can be certain: there is no question of letting agriculture be governed in our world.â

Located just 50 kilometers from Rabat, the village of Brachoua came out of poverty in two years. The key: Permaculture, on the initiative of the sixty families of the village.  Three years ago Brachoua had neither running water nor electricity. Today, the village has two fountains and has registered its name as a destination for hikers and trekkers, curious about the beauty of the place and eager to see the impact of permaculture on the village

Ireland is called The Green Island because of its stunning and overwhelming greenery. Now it is well on its way to be known as Green in more than one sense. Green Energy in the form of Community Power is a small, but growing industry. There are only a handful of community owned energy projects in operation at present, however support is mounting and change is afoot. Wind Power and Bioenergy projects dominate the market at present.
Community Power and Renewable Energy Storage in Denmark and in the EU Renewable Energy Needs Storage! Conference: 12 December 2016 Nordic Folkecenter for Renewable Energi  Renewable energies are the best solution for the future, but they have a problem in continuity: due to their nature, they tend to fluctuate, meaning that storage systems are vital for the renewable energy transition. This conference will analyse both the different solutions available on the market and the future ones. International experts will present their findings and discuss which solution will be the best for the society.  https://www.facebook.com/events/580722238782135/?ti=cl
The CONFERENCE is open to everyone who has an interest in renewable energies. The REGISTRATION fee is 100 DKK (for covering the meals) and the deadline for registering is DECEMBER 9.  Furthermore, on the 13th of December there will be the possibility of joining a study tour, which will bring you inside a working wind turbine.  More information can be found on

"A transformation is happening in global energy markets thatâs worth noting as 2016 comes to an end: Solar power, for the first time, is becoming the cheapest form of new electricity.   This has happened in isolated projects in the past: an especially competitive auction in the Middle East, for example, resulting in record-cheap solar costs. But now unsubsidized solar is beginning to outcompete coal and natural gas on a larger scale, and notably, new solar projects in emerging markets are costing less to build than wind projects, according to fresh data from Bloomberg New Energy Finance."

"Wind energy has reached new heights in Denmark with the inauguration of two new wind turbines, which are able to produce electricity for more than 18.000 Danish households. With a height of 200 meters, wingspan of 164 meters together with an 8MW production capacity, the wind turbines are now the largest in the world.  The wind turbines produce so much power that 300 of them would be enough to supply all households in Denmark. The main investor European Energy sees this as a big step for wind energy."

"The speed in which this trait was expressed in the urban-dwelling plants surprised the researchers.  Professor Alberti said the changes that were observed in more than 1,600 studies were having an impact on evolution and that human activity, in the form of urbanisation, would have a lasting legacy on life on Earth.  These findings add weight to the idea that the planet is now entering an Anthropocene epoch, a geological measurement of time in which humans are having a significant global impact on the Earth's geology and ecosystems."

"A long-running rift in the Larsen C ice shelf grew suddenly in December and now just 20km of ice is keeping the 5,000 sq km piece from floating away.  Larsen C is the most northern major ice shelf in Antarctica.  Researchers based in Swansea say the loss of a piece a quarter of the size of Wales will leave the whole shelf vulnerable to future break-up.  Larsen C is about 350m thick and floats on the seas at the edge of West Antarctica, holding back the flow of glaciers that feed into it. "

"All of the electric passenger trains running in the Netherlands are now powered entirely by wind. One year ahead of schedule, Dutch railway company NS announced its entire electric train fleet is running on 100-percent wind power as of January 1, 2017, ushering in a new era of green transportation. Renewable energy advocates hope the early success will inspire planners to incorporate wind-powered trains in other high-speed rail projects around the world, including some proposed in the United States."

International Womens Day 2017  A Letter to Leaders  You couldn't be where you are today without a good education. But because poverty is sexist, 130 million girls across the world are denied this basic right. Indeed, if the number of girls out of school formed a country, it would be the tenth largest on the planet - bigger than Japan or Germany. All children deserve a good education, but in the poorest countries girls are denied it more often than boys. Education is vital for moving out of poverty. Every additional year of school that a girl completes increases her future earnings, which is good for her family, her community and her country. We cannot afford to squander the potential of 130 million girls to cure diseases or end wars, invent brilliant technology or revolutionise an industry... or simply to access opportunity. We are coming together and uniting across our divides to get every girl into school and to make sure she gets a quality education once she's there. But we need you to do the same. Your education helped you to get where you are today - and it is in your power to help millions of girls to get theirs. Please act now, with the right policies and the necessary funds. Show us that politics can work for the people - starting with the people who need it most.  IF YOU CARE, ACT ADD YOUR NAME TODAY  Name

"Air pollution is linked to around 40,000 premature deaths a year in the UK, and transport also makes up a significant share of greenhouse gas emissions.  A government spokesman said: "Poor air quality is the biggest environmental risk to public health in the UK and this government is determined to take strong action in the shortest time possible."
"Two million tonnes of clothes are purchased every year, of which one million tonnes are thrown away.  That is, exactly 50% of the total clothes purchased end up in a landfill. Most cheap clothes are made from polyester, comprising extremely strong, non-biodegradable fibre, even resistant to most forms of chemicals.  Tonnes of disposable clothes from the developed countries are shipped to East African countries. In Germany, around where I live, huge metal boxes painted in bright colours, in street corners, invite people to donate their clothes and shoes, supposedly to clothe the poor African folks.  While it eases the guilt arising from excessive consumerism, most of these clothes end up in a landfill, albeit only in a distant land. The salvaged ones, though, fuel a thriving second-hand clothing economy, resulting in severe pressure on the local players in the home-grown markets in Africa.  This prompted six East African nations, Kenya, Uganda, Rwanda, Burundi, Tanzania and South Sudan, to decide on a ban on imported second-hand clothes and shoes by the year 2019."

I Â»Ikke uden min morÂ« fortÃ¦ller og lÃ¦gger vi Ã¸rer til hinandens kvindehistorier. Det gÃ¦lder alle kvinder til alle tider og i alle kulturer. Ingen kvinde eksisterer uden sin mor.   I kan komme til os pÃ¥ teatret danskdansk, der ligger pÃ¥ Frederikssundsvej 62, baghuset, kÃ¦lderen, 2400 KÃ¸benhavn NV, eller vi kan komme til jer: hjemme hos jer selv, i foreningen, kvindeklubben eller den lokale cafÃ©. Interviewene vil blive foretaget af bl.a. instruktÃ¸ren amerikansk/koreansk/danske Sandra Yi Sencindiver og dramatikeren norsk/gambiansk Camara Christina Lundestad Joof fra teater danskdansk. MÃ¸derne vil foregÃ¥ i uge 34 of 35 - de sidste 2 uger af august.    EfterfÃ¸lgende i september, december og februar vil forestillingen blive skabt. Til udvalgte prÃ¸ver (2 timer om eftermiddagen eller aftenen) vil vi gerne invitere jer til at bl.a. mÃ¸des med skuespillerne, vÃ¦re med til prÃ¸ver, se skitser og idÃ©er. "A fresh outbreak of violence in Myanmar's Rakhine state has caused hundreds of thousands of Rohingya civilians to flee to Bangladesh. The exodus began on 25 August after Rohingya militants attacked police posts, killing 12 members of the security forces. Those attacks led to a security crackdown. Myanmar's military says it is fighting insurgents but those who have fled say troops and Rakhine Buddhists are conducting a brutal campaign to drive them out. The Rohingya - a stateless mostly Muslim minority group - have faced years of persecution in Myanmar. Deep-seated tensions between them and the majority Buddhist population in Rakhine have led to deadly communal violence in the past."

"People outraged by the banning of Icelandâs Christmas advert on TV are taking action by signing a petition appealing for the decision to be overturned.  The advert, which was banned by the advertising regulatory body for being âtoo politicalâ, has sparked anger on social media from people who disagree with it being kept off our TVs.   The high-street supermarket elected to do something different this festive period and, rather than focus on tables filled with festive food, highlight an important environmental issue in their ad.  The banned animation â originally created by Greenpeace and now available to view on YouTube â  tells the story of rainforest destruction caused by palm oil production via its impact on an endangered orangutan. In April 2018, Iceland pledged to remove palm oil from all its own-brand food lines. The advert failed to secure approval on the grounds of it being âseen to support a political issueâ."
PLEASE SIGN THIS PETITION AND SAVE THE RAIN FORESTS FOR THE ORANGUTANS.    Mark Topps started this petition to ClearCast.  "Iceland released a Christmas advert today highlighting the devastation caused by palm oil products. It was a beautiful and important message. But the tv regulators have banned the advert, for being too political!  Palm oil is a product that can be found in everything from shampoos and detergents to sandwiches and biscuits.. Itâs one of the most environmentally-damaging industries, and each day 25 orangutans are killed. Itâs production wipes out rainforests and wildlife, driving animals like the orangutan into extinction.  As a father of three who thinks this ad would help educate people about how their products are killing orangutans and their homes, I feel banning this advert is an injustice.  The body that stopped the advert being broadcasted, Clearcast, say that the ad breaches itâs political rules. The ad holds an important message - one that is emotional, touching and helps to spread a message about saving the environment and so must be broadcasted. If you havenât watched it, you can find it here. Itâs so powerful.  Please sign this petition if you too believe the ban should be overturned so that this ad can be on TV screens at Christmas."  #NoPalmOilChristmas #SaveTheOrangutans

"An old coal power station is set to be transformed into a âsustainable villageâ of 2,000 homes powered by solar panels, in the biggest redevelopment yet of a former UK power plant.  French firm Engie said it had decided against selling off the Rugeley site in Staffordshire and would instead build super efficient houses on the 139-hectare site as part of its bid to âmove beyond energyâ.  Half of the energy required by the new homes will come from green sources, predominantly solar, which will be fitted on rooftops, in a field and even floating on a lake.  The company is planning for 10 megawatts of solar capacity in total, equivalent to one of the UKâs smaller solar farms.  Batteries will be used across the site, both in homes and at a communal power storage facility, to balance out electricity supply and demand.  The firm is also claiming the homes will be so efficient they will use nearly a third less energy than average new builds. Heating will come not from gas boilers but electric devices such as heat pumps."
"The second largest rainforest in the world â in Central Africaâs Congo Basin â is disappearing at an alarming rate, despite local laws against deforestation.  A new study out of the University of California names China and the United States as the primary culprits.  China more than doubled its wood imports from the Congo Basin between 2001 and 2015, the study found, and most of the cheap furniture it exported was headed for the United States."

""However, the proposed release of GM âmale-sterileâ mosquitoes, meant to only be for training purposes, is not expected to deliver any benefits for malaria control in Burkina Faso. This is not an early stage trial for later releases of the gene drive mosquitoes, but releases of an entirely different GM mosquito.  Instead, the release of the GM mosquito poses risks, including the incidental release of some biting female GM mosquitoes during the experiments. While Target Malaria claims that the number will be small, nevertheless, since GM female mosquitoes can bite humans and spread disease, the release of biting females still poses some risk to local people.  Furthermore, there is evidence that Target Malaria is paying compensation of 400 CFA francs (approximately 70 US cents) per hour to local villagers to allow for the collection of biting female mosquitoes from their own bodies.  The use of a financial incentive to individuals to expose themselves to biting female mosquitoes, and potentially to malaria, is also ethically extremely questionableâ, said Dr. Helen Wallace, Director of GeneWatch UK."

"What should we do when our government is leading us off the cliff edge? Iâve tried the conventional things. Iâve voted in elections, signed petitions, and written letters to my MP. Iâve been on marches, and given money to organisations like Greenpeace and Avaaz.   Iâve joined the Green party, and delivered leaflets and knocked on doors. Iâve started petitions, and had conversations with people about how the climate is changing. Iâm not really sure that any of these things has had any positive effect, but I am sure that twelve more years of doing the same wonât be enough. By then we may have reached the point of runaway climate change. There isnât time to wait for politicians to come to their senses.  Thatâs why Iâve joined the Extinction Rebellion campaign.  Itâs using tried and tested methods of nonviolent civil disobedience: methods that worked for Gandhi and Martin Luther King, for the suffragettes, and for countless campaigns and struggles around the world. "Living in a tiny home doesn't have to mean sacrificing style or comfort, as evidenced by this tiny stunner created by former boat builder and current owner of tiny home company Room to Move, Jeff Hobbs.  Thanks to a 600-watt solar power system and a rainwater collection system on the roof, the self-sustaining home is designed to be entirely off the grid. Water is heated by a solar collector and a woodstove, while laundry equipment is stored in a utility shed on the side of the house. Jeff designed the home for client Briar Hale, and Living Big In A Tiny House's YouTube channel recently posted a video tour of the space." https://offgridquest.com/tinyhouse/solar-powered-tiny-home?fbclid=IwAR0CHGaY0tEDL4f5PHEOGGSLLO1dOTKoUEzw-zEvG9aTB_qiQUkwiOyTG4A

"â¬ 58 million for electricity and contract farming in Burkina Faso  Paris finances the largest energy project in Burkina Faso. Last Tuesday, the BurkinabÃ¨ government and the French Development Agency (AFD) met to sign a â¬ 58 million financing agreement for the "Dorsale Nord" Regional Power Interconnector Project and the Contract Farming and Ecological Transition Project (PACTE).  More specifically, three conventions have been signed. The first two concern "Dorsale Nord" with an envelope of â¬ 45 million - including â¬ 30 million from France and â¬ 15 million from the EU - for the construction of 381 km of very high voltage line between Burkina Faso and Niger, the strengthening of transport infrastructure around Ouagadougou, and the electrification of 150 localities, which represents approximately 100,000 inhabitants. "Dorsale Nord" allows Burkina Faso to import electricity via regional interconnections and develop renewable energies. "With the signing of this project, it will allow us to have access to energy more than 50% cheaper than our local production," said the Minister of Economy. A project that is part of the West African Power Exchange System (WAPP) with a total cost of â¬ 600 million, which is the connection of Nigeria to the network of Niger, Burkina Faso and Benin.  The third convention concerns PACTE with a grant of â¬ 13 million granted by the European Union to AFD. These resources will be used through a call for projects that will be launched during the year after a selection of projects. The objective of PACTE is to promote contract farming, to intensify agroecology, and to professionalize actors in the sector. At the same time, the PACTE facilitates the arrival of private investors in agribusiness through a better structuring and professionalisation of producers, a strengthening of economic links between actors in the sector, and the transmission of future agricultural innovations. .  Remember that the signing of these three conventions relating to development projects is part of the National Plan for Economic and Social Development (PNDES) adopted in 2016 by the Burkinabe government."
"The African Climate Week opens today in Ghana, bringing together multilateral organizations such as UNDP, the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) and the World Bank, as well as investors and other stakeholders in advancing national climate action plans or nationally determined contributions (NDCs), UNDP stresses.  This week is preparing African countries for the next United Nations conference on climate change - the COP25 - to be held in Chile in December, but before that the UN Secretary-General's Climate Summit in September.  In view of these global events, a series of regional climate weeks is planned in Africa, Asia-Pacific, Latin America and the Caribbean.  "Financing the global transition to a low-carbon, climate-resilient economy will require an investment of at least $ 60 trillion.The public sector's financial commitment of $ 100 billion per year must be used to mobilize strategically and minimize the risks of private investment to accelerate the fight against climate change. We must urgently invest in new technologies where they are most needed. This African Climate Week is so much needed and well received, "said Abdoulaye Mar Dieye, UN Under-Secretary-General and Director of UNDP's Office of Development Policy.  Approximately 85 to 90 percent of the funds needed to achieve the Paris Agreement's objectives will come from the private sector. With current flows far from sufficient, it is essential to bring investors and decision-makers together. Hence the opening of African Week and a two-day forum on private sector investment for projects bringing climate solutions to Ghana's challenges."

SIR DAVID ATTENBOROUGH: "We are facing a man-made disaster on a global scale."   "We are running out of time, but there is still hope. I believe that if we better understand the threats we face, the more likely it is that we can avoid such a catastrophic future."
"Global carbon levels from 2010 needed to be cut by almost half by 2030, limiting global warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius, otherwise the world could be locked into catastrophic climate change.  Many governments are falling short of the commitments they made at the 2015 Paris climate change conference to cut fossil fuel emissions.  In the void left by government inaction, scientists have for years been quietly working on extreme, last-ditch solutions to slow global warming.  These solutions â an attempt to re-engineer the climate system â are known as geoengineering.  Critics say there is a risk that climate hacking will give government and industry an excuse to keep burning the planet.  But no matter how fast the world switches to renewable energy, the age of untested, high-risk geoengineering could soon be upon us.  So what are the most likely fixes and would they really work?" Beautiful and eco-friendly house built in the traditional ârammed earthâ technique using locally sourced materials by @[465366930319001:274:Hive Earth], a construction company based in Accra, Ghana.   To make the house eco-friendly, not only to build but also to live in, the company can install an underground cooling system. By digging around 8 feet or more into the ground they get to the cool air underground and with the use of a solar pump the cool air is constantly brought into the home. The cost of the solar pump is around $300 and then there will be no electricity bills to pay for the air con.  Hive Earth's aim is to build houses that their workers and the majority of Ghanaians and West Africans can afford. A one-room house will cost roughly $5,000. The prototype should be ready by the end of 2019.  Read the article by clicking the picture below.

AFROPUNK May 10, 2019: "âBrick Houseâ is a New York rarity not only in that it is a statue of a woman, but of a Black woman. The cityâs so famously short of such pieces that recently its first lady, Charline McCray, helped launch a public arts initiative to make and install such works around the five boroughs. Yet as with all truly great public art, its representational importance is only a part of what makes Leighâs statue a monumental, therapeutic tour de force. Timing, placement and intent (creative, political, otherwise) all matter. And like the Commodores song the title echoes and whose lyrical metaphors it evokes, âBrick Houseâ is foundational in both how it literally establishes a public image of strong Black femininity, and the meaning brought forth by its 2019 presence in this particular space. In her proximity, the world we populate feels different." https://afropunk.com/2019/05/public-art-therapy-simone-leigh-brick-house/#

WAY TO GO!!  ð "France has now set the benchmark in the global effort to save the bees and prevent âecological Armageddon.â  The country banned all 5 of the neonicotinoid pesticides that researchers are blaming for collapsing bee populations.  The move follows the European Unionâs ban of  the three worst offenders â clothianidin, imidacloprid and thiamethoxam â in crop fields starting last month.  France has banned these three along with thiacloprid and acetamiprid, not only outdoors but in greenhouses too.  Studies have shown that neonicotinoids cut beesâ sperm count and scramble their memory and homing skills. The latest research suggests  bees can develop a dangerous addiction to the insecticides, much like smokers for nicotine.  The ban is celebrated by beekeepers and environmentalists, but cereal and sugar beet farmers warn it could leave them defenseless in protecting their crops against harmful insects,  The Telegraph reports.  Introduced in the mid-1990s, synthetic neonicotinoids share the chemical structure of nicotine and attack the central nervous system of insects.  The United Nations warned last year that 40 percent of pollinators â particularly bees and butterflies â risk global extinction."

"Necessity, they say is the mother of inventions and a young Ghanaian man, Richard Kwarteng Aning, together with his team has given credence to the saying. Reiterating the need for safety from Coronavirus, the 32-year-old has manufactured a hand-washing sink powered by solar energy.  How it works: Being a sensor, the sink pours out soap upon detection and begins sounding an alarm to get the individual ready for the outflow of water. The sink has been programmed such that as soon as the alarm goes off, water flows out for 25 seconds, enough to get hands thoroughly cleaned. The mavericks created the system in a two-way channel, one to pump clean water and the other to drain soapy water, after which it flows out from a tap beneath the sink. This invention has solved the problem of having to open and close taps, therby re-staining hands with germs."  https://www.adomonline.com/ghanaian-invents-sensor-hand-washing-sink-from-scraps-photosvideo/?fbclid=IwAR2mdm7BTB2Shh68i5qermCaFG_MU9sediVRnjOBrcOWJr228FQM17UjSyY

"Peter Gladson is India's First & only one-man-band who plays more than 13 instruments (Ukulele, drums, harmonica to name a few), all at once! Gladson is carrying 25 kg of instruments on himself and coordinating 13 instruments He is inspiring both young and old to push themselves to their limits and follow their passion. 25 years old, 25 kgs, 13 instruments and a set of damaged lungs, one needs to experience his magic, first hand."
